Award.AwardTitle: Windows on the Inquiry Classroom: Full Course, Instructor-and-Apprentice Annotated Video for Professional Development in STEM Inquiry Teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In their teaching practices, STEM faculty find it difficult to break out of the mode of straight lecture presentation, even though many of them are aware of modern research on teaching and learning. One reason is that they hardly ever visit each other's classrooms. They do not have good examples of how the classroom could look different, and they do not have opportunities to talk with other instructors about why they do what they do. Courses and workshops that train new faculty members also lack concrete models of actual classroom practice.

This project is creating a full, professionally produced video record of an existing course called "Fire and Ice," which is an example of inquiry-based instruction, in which students build their understanding of scientific concepts through group discussions and hands-on scientific explorations. The teaching approaches are derived from current research on human learning and motivation. The classroom here is not a scripted, perfect classroom; it is a real classroom, in which instructors and students face real learning challenges. The video is being tagged with video commentary from interviews with course participants, including the instructor (a chemistry professor), students (non-science majors), and several science Ph.D. students who are novice co-teachers for the course. The annotated video provides a science classroom with an open door. Instructors, both experienced and novice, explain their goals, decisions, and attitudes. The viewer therefore experiences a story line (the course as it happens) as well as a backstory (the motivations, attitudes, and responses of participants). Hence the word "windows" in the project title -- there are multiple views into this classroom. An individual user of the video can "visit" the course to see what is going on and can "talk" with the instructor about his thinking.

The video product is expected to be downloadable on the Web, for use by people who want to improve their teaching or explore inquiry-based approaches, and for use in classes and workshops for training teachers.

About the course: "Fire and Ice" is a course for non-science majors, focusing on the perception, movement, creation, understanding, and use of heat. It incorporates scientific principles from chemistry, physics, biology, physiology, and history of science. Topics include, for example, how the body senses heat and regulates temperature; how heat is used in cooking via baking, broiling, and microwaving; how heat moves through atomic/molecular motion; and how to make ice in warm climates. Historical literature from the 18th century is often used for readings. Each class session is structured on a learning cycle format, beginning with hands-on explorations, which move to abstract models and then to applications that have personal or societal relevance. Students work throughout the course in cooperative groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teachers in the United States rarely have the chance to see each other at work with students. This is true from pre-school up through graduate study. This means that teachers are missing opportunities to ask each other detailed questions about their teaching choices, and to observe the results of those choices. All of these important moments for improving the practices of teaching and for improving the learning of students are gone. This project "Windows on the Inquiry Classroom" shows how to surmount this problem. We taught and captured in full an inquiry-based college course called "Fire and Ice" about heat, temperature, and energy. This is a nearly lecture-less class in which students working in teams are guided through critical experiments and discussions of physiology, chemistry, physics, biology, and engineering. The door to this classroom is open at any time as a free open-access resource:

https://scholars.unh.edu/bauer                       This is the database stored in the UNH Scholars Repository.

https://mypages.unh.edu/windows-stem-inquiry      This is the "front door"website for orientation.

All 27 class sessions are captured in 10-minute video segments from four angles, including instructor and student teams. All course documents are also available: daily agenda, student team instructions and work products, and hands-on activity procedures. There are behind-the-curtain stories as well: instructor previews and debriefing for each class, graduate interns reviewing every class, student focus groups, and videos about course design process. We like to call it a Pedagogic Field Site because it is like an outdoor nature site that one can walk into and explore. The site has multiple purposes:  (1) to be a source of materials and ideas for teaching about heat and temperature, (2) to be a detailed example of inquiry-based STEM instruction, (3) to be a resource for teacher professional development, and (4) to be a database for STEM education research investigations.

The intellectual merit of this project is that the video product will make the inquiry classroom real for many STEM instructors -- real in the sense that they can visit the classroom, listen to how an experienced instructor implements his pedagogical content knowledge, and peer over the shoulder of novice instructors as they build their confidence and experience. The "Fire and Ice" course is an authentic, not staged implementation.  Some aspects of the course will be strong in supporting student learning and other aspects may show areas in need of improvement.  All of this is fodder for discussion of pedagogy and learning. 

The broader impact is that the video product can be incorporated into teacher professional development workshops for individual study, group discussion, or research.  In addition, the door to this classroom is open at any time, and there are no physical or geographic limitations. The project also encourages the development of additional documentary resources as a means for enhancing our understanding of teaching processes.
